citeinfo.title: Salt marsh viability (regularly and irregularly flooded) by census block group in 2050 under a 1m sea level rise by 2100 scenario for Corpus Christi Bay, Texas.

serinfo.sername: TNC Coastal Conservation and Resiliency Analyses

pubinfo.pubplace: 205 N. Carizzo Street, Corpus Christi, TX, 78401, US

citeinfo.title: Informing conservation and resiliency planning using sea-level rise and storm-surge scenario impact estimates in Corpus Christi Bay

serinfo.sername: TNC Coastal Conservation and Resiliency Analyses

descript.abstract: This dataset shows the most and least viable salt marshes (irregularly flooded and regularly flooded) by census block group in 2050 under a 1 meter SLR scenario. Marsh viability was calculated by comparing the initial marsh footprint within each census block to that which is predicted to remain by 2100. This was accomplished by summing marsh losses, gains and persistence and dividing that by the initial marsh area within the census block group. The 5 classes shown (1= high viability and 5=Low viability) were classified based on a Natural Breaks classification which helps to show maximum differences in marsh viability per census block group. Census blocks which did not intitally contain salt marsh but gained marsh by 2100 were given a rank of 6 and those without marsh were given a rank of 6. This dataset is based on results from the application of SLAMM.
descript.purpose: This file was created for The Nature Conservancy's Sea Level Rise Project for the northern Gulf of Mexico with funding from the Coastal Bend Bays and Estuary Program (CBBEP). The map represents the viability of salt marshes (regularly and irregularly flooded) by census block group, which were derived from predicted landcover maps of Corpus Christi Bay, Texas. This dataset shows predicted salt marsh viability in 2050 within census block groups under a 1m SLR scenario by 2100. The viability ranking dataset excludes blocks where salt marsh did not exist in the intital landcover dataset (rank = 0). The landcover maps used for the study area were derived from Sea Level Rise Affecting Marsh Model (SLAMM) using the 1m of sea-level rise by 2100 scenario which predict how marshes might migrate inland due to increasing sea levels.

procstep.procdesc: TNC Conservation and Resiliency analyses were created from SLAMM and ADCIRC modeling outputs for Corpus Christi Bay, Texas (see reports at www.SLRportal.org)

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Unique identifier for each block group

attrdomv.udom: Area in sq. meters defining the features.
Area (sq. meters) defining the intital marsh footprint within the features.
Area (sq. meters) of marsh loss by block group
Area (sq. meters) of marsh gain by block group
Area (sq. meters) of marsh persistence by block group
Viability scores calculated by summing area of marsh gains, loses and persistence
Viaibility index calculated by dividing the viability score by the initial marsh area
Viability ranking descriptions based on VIAB_R from low to high
